Monetary policy can only have a direct, positive effect on employment in short, temp spurts, at the cost of future econ growth & employment.
In response to “stagflation,” Congress gave the Fed a dual mandate assigning equal weight to achieving stable prices and full employment.
During the 80s & 90s, Chairmen Volcker & Greenspan conducted monetary policy as if the Fed had a single mandate for price stability.
Fed failed its role as lender of last resort between 1929 & 1933, leading to unnecessary bank failures, intensifying the Great Depression.
While the early Fed was successful in providing an elastic currency, eliminating the frequent, seasonal financial panics of the 19th century
